paper.title: A Bayesian observer model constrained by efficient coding can explain anti-Bayesian percepts

claims.text: Efficient coding and Bayesian decoding are often treated separately; this work unifies them in one constrained observer model.
If encoding is efficient with respect to natural stimulus statistics, Bayesian decoding can produce repulsive (anti-Bayesian-looking) perceptual biases.
If standard symmetric-likelihood Bayesian models are sufficient, repulsive biases and differential noise-source effects should not require efficient-coding constraints.
Model constrains prior and likelihood jointly via Fisher-information-based efficient coding, then performs Bayesian decoding with explicit loss function.
External stimulus noise and internal sensory noise have opposite effects on bias direction/magnitude.
The framework explains both orientation and spatial-frequency psychophysical bias data.
Apparent anti-Bayesian behavior can be Bayes-optimal once realistic encoding constraints are included.
